captions.text:
The next thing that we are going to do is
teach our dogs to back up and the reason why

i like the back up the best is because if
you have a dog that is very exuberant with

their toys and like to jump can actually tell
them to back up and wait for their toy so

that they can go and get their toys. Jake
come, good boy, drop, good boy and the way

that we would do this, is a couple ways you
can do this. The first one, if you have a

dog that backs up easy would be to take you
treat and just back in to him, back back,

back, back, back, good boy and give him a
treat. He has progressed really quick because

he knows it. You would start with little baby
steps, come, by actually just walking in to

him and one step back would get a treat. Another
easy way to do this is to bring him through

a row of chairs. Where you would bring him
through the row of chairs so that they can

get out and just start going backwards as
they are doing it tell them good boy. And

then you would add the hand signal and the
word and what you would do it just tell him

back, back, back, good boy. So your end result
is you should get a dog that you can tell

them back, back, back, come forward, go back,
so that they learn to be maneuvered a whole

title: Dog Tricks : Backing Up Dog Trick

comments.text:
i'm having trouble teaching this to my puggle pup. his tendency is to 
always sit and look up to me. whenever he's standing and i try to get him 
to back up, he'll take one step back then plop down & sit. by then it's 
halfway late for me because I've already either clicked or said yes (from 
the first back up step he took). any suggestions to get him to keep backing 
up instead of plopping would be appreciated, thanks!﻿

comments.text:
@blah2332232 You can try to just "walk into them", if they see you as the 
pack leader rather than food dispenser, they should try to avoid being in 
your way. Also if she sits, you tell her no and get her to stand up. 
Babysteps, sometimes people progress too quickly with training which leads 
to confusion in the dog. (Something I did when teaching my dog leash 
obedience)
